Review Research status and prospect of separators for magnesium-sulfur batteries Shaopeng Chen Yaru Wang Yukun Sun Duo Zhang Shuxin Zhang Yazhen Zhao Jiulin Wang Jun Yang Yanna NuLi ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Electrochemical Energy Devices Research Center, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shanghai Electrochemical Energy Devices Research Center Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Electrochemical Energy Devices Research Center, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphic abstract Different types of separator modification strategies have been proposed for Mg-S batteries to effectively suppress the shuttle effect of polysulfides and achieve a high-level battery performance. Magnesium-sulfur (Mg-S) batteries have attracted wide research attention in recent years, and are considered as one of the major candidates to replace lithium-ion batteries due to the high theoretical energy density, low costs of active materials, and high safety. However, there are still significant challenges that need to be overcome before they can reach the large-scale practical applications. The key issue is the dissolution and shuttle effect of magnesium polysulfides (Mg-PSs), which leads to severe capacity degradation and shortens cycling life, greatly limiting the development of Mg-S batteries. In order to overcome these challenges, great efforts have been made in cathode materials, electrolytes, and separators. Herein, we review the investigations on suppressing the shuttle effect of Mg-PSs via the modification of separators, including schemes such as coating the functional materials that can hold Mg-PSs on the surface of polyolefin-based or glass fiber (GF) separators, forming gel polymer separators via cross-linking polymerization reactions, and developing gel polymer electrolytes coupled with GF separators. Furthermore, an outlook is proposed for the future design on separator exploitation to accelerate the development of Mg-S battery technology. Keywords Magnesium-sulfur batteries Polysulfides Shuttle effect Separator modification Gel polymer electrolytes 1 Introduction The development and utilization of renewable energy, such as solar energy, bioenergy and ocean energy, have become the major trend of energy development in recent years, but these sustainable energy sources are greatly limited by the natural climate [1]. Among energy storage systems based on renewable energy sources, secondary batteries have become the key focus of researchers around the world due to their advantages such as no geographical and climatic restrictions, wide range of applications and mass production, etc. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have become the ideal power source in the 21st century owing to the outstanding advantages of light mass, high capacity, long cycle life, and no memory effect [2–4]. LIBs are widely used in portable electronic products such as mobile phones and laptops. Meanwhile, they have been promoted in electric vehicles, aerospace and military equipment through the comprehensive optimization of battery performance [5,6]. However, there are still some non-negligible issues hindering the further development of LIBs, such as the safety problems caused by Li dendrite deposition, the energy density close to the theoretical limit and the high price of Li metal arising from the limited Li resources in the earth’s crust [7–9]. Therefore, the development of advanced secondary batteries with high energy densities, high safety and low costs has become a hot topic of global attention. Magnesium-sulfur (Mg-S) batteries are competitive candidates for energy storage due to the low costs, high theoretical energy density, and good safety [10–12]. Compared to Li metal, Mg is more abundant in nature (Mg is one of the most abundant metal elements in the earth's crust). Moreover, Mg anode is less likely to produce dendrites during charging and discharging processes of the batteries, but tends to grow in planar crystallization from the current research [13–16]. In addition, some significant advantages such as high theoretical specific capacities (mass capacity of 2205 mA h g−1 and volumetric capacity of 3833 mA h cm−3) [17], relatively low reduction potential (−2.37 V vs. SHE) [18,19], lower costs than Li [20–22], and processability under atmospheric environment make Mg metal an ideal anode of secondary batteries with high energy density (Fig. 1 a). Meanwhile, elemental sulfur (S8) has become an attractive cathode material due to its high theoretical mass capacity (1672 mA h g−1) [23] and great natural abundance. Therefore, Mg-S batteries with remarkable theoretical energy density of 1700 Wh kg−1 and 3200 Wh L−1 have great application prospects in the energy storage fields [24–26]. In total, although Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely applied in many commercial fields, considering the high requirements for battery systems in the future energy storage fields, LIBs still need to further break through key bottlenecks such as the ultimate capacity and safety hazards caused by lithium dendrites. In addition, the low abundance of Li in nature and high market price are also critical factors restricting the sustainable development of LIBs. On the contrary, Mg-S batteries are seldom limited by the key indexes of energy storage devices, such as energy density, safety, and costs, and thus are more suitable for the new energy world in the future. However, compared to the relatively mature lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery technology, the research on Mg-S batteries is still in the early stage of development, with the first report on Mg-S batteries appearing in 2011 [27]. Typically, Mg-S and Li-S batteries are considered to be quite similar by scientific practitioners due to the diagonal position of Mg and Li in the periodic table of the elements with similar chemical properties. However, the existence of differences is a point that deserves more attentions. The essential differences between the two sulfur-based battery systems have been compared side-by-side, including variations in the reactivity of the two metal anodes with commonly used electrolytes, and differences in the stability, solubility, and redox behavior of polysulfides in different electrolytes [28]. Indeed, the origin of the differences between the two battery systems stems from the different nature of the metal Li and Mg, which means that there are limited references from Li-S batteries when conducting Mg-S battery studies. Fig. 1(b and c) generally show the similarities and differences between Mg-S and Li-S batteries. In Mg-S batteries, there are still many key technical and scientific issues that need to be addressed. The primary issue is the lack of suitable electrolytes, and the common magnesium electrolytes have their own drawbacks. The chlorine-containing species in the electrolytes, which are the key active components for the reversible electrochemical Mg plating/stripping, can inevitably cause the corrosion to the current collector or battery shell [29–31]. Moreover, magnesium salts, solvents, and trace impurities in the electrolytes may react adversely with Mg metal to form an interfacial passivation layer, which hinders the migration of Mg2+ ions and causes a high impedance of the Mg anode, resulting in the increase of overpotential and low Coulombic efficiency of Mg plating/stripping [15,32]. In fact, the impedance of the Mg anode is higher compared to the sulfur cathode, which dominates the impedance of the Mg-S batteries [33], while these challenges are more easily solved in Li-S batteries. Some investigations found that the overpotential resulted from passivation of Mg anode could be largely reduced by pre-modification of Mg metal surface [34–37]. In addition, sulfur is an electrophilic material that easily reacts with nucleophilic electrolytes, leading to rapid battery failure [27]. Therefore, the research and development on non-nucleophilic electrolytes that are safe and stable, non-corrosive, chemically compatible with sulfur cathode, and reversible Mg plating/stripping are the key technology challenges of Mg-S batteries [38–40]. Up to now, numerous efforts have been made to improve the electrochemical performance of Mg-S batteries by designing the electrolytes [27,41–47]. For sulfur cathode, the intrinsic electronic/ionic insulation of sulfur and its reduction products (MgS2 and MgS), as well as the slow reaction kinetics and poor electrochemical reversibility of the products, result in insufficient cycling stability and rate capability. Therefore, the battery system cannot achieve comprehensive performance under high rate conditions [48], for which extensive efforts have been made to regulate the microstructure of sulfur/carbon nanomaterials [49–51]. Similar to Li-S batteries, a notorious shuttle effect remains another great challenge that hinders the practical application of Mg-S batteries [52–54]. The so-called “shuttle effect”, i.e., the discharge intermediate magnesium polysulfides (Mg-PSs) dissolve in the liquid electrolytes and diffuse through the separators to the Mg anode, where undesired side reactions occur, leading to a low utilization of sulfur materials and rapid capacity degradation of the batteries [55–57]. In addition, the diffusion of Mg-PSs causes passivation of Mg anode, which is also responsible for the poor cycling performance of Mg-S batteries [58]. In order to relieve the shuttle effect, many strategies have been investigated in metal-sulfur batteries [59]. In Li-S batteries, researchers have conducted extensive explorations on cathode matrix materials. In particular, following the pioneering work of Nazar et al. [60], the strategies of mitigating the shuttle effect and volume expansion and improving the performance of Li-S batteries by accommodating sulfur in the conductive carbon matrix materials have been widely reported [7,61–71]. Similar approaches have been effectively applied in Mg-S batteries, including confining sulfur in stable and efficient conductive hosts such as graphene, graphdiyne, porous carbon materials, carbon nanotubes, and conducting polymers [49,50,72–74]. In addition, considering the polarity of polysulfides, the introduction of polar molecules interacting with polysulfides (e.g., oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus, boron, their corresponding metal inorganic compounds, etc.) into the cathode matrix materials to chemically immobilize polysulfides is of appealing research significance. In addition, using electrolytes that are stable to polysulfides or introducing additives into the electrolytes to inhibit shuttle effect are also effective strategies in both Li-S and Mg-S battery systems [41,42,61–63,75]. Differently, the inhibition of lithium dendrite growth and shuttle effect by developing solid electrolytes has been reported in Li-S batteries [76–78], but the study of all-solid-state electrolytes (ASSEs) in Mg-S batteries is still almost at the initial stage. Nevertheless, researchers found that the structures of gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs) coupled with separators exhibited favorable shuttle effect inhibition in Mg-S batteries, which contributed well to the improvement of the performance of Mg-S batteries. In addition, due to the difference in metallicity, the passivation effect of polysulfides on metal Mg is more serious than Li. Therefore, in Mg-S batteries, researchers have also developed stable Mg anodes to reduce the negative impact of the shuttle effect, such as usage of Mg-Li alloy [79] and Mg-based alloy with liquid metal gallium (Ga) layer [80]. These efforts have yielded good results, and a systematic overview on the anodes, cathodes and electrolytes of Mg-S batteries has been reported [81]. However, as important components of the liquid electrolyte batteries, separators have also non-negligible impacts on the performance of the batteries, especially for the Mg-S batteries. Considering that the polysulfides passing through the separator experience the shuttle effect, functional separators can be designed to adsorb or block the polysulfides and restrict the shuttling, thus improving the utilization of sulfur materials, avoiding the passivation of anodes, and improving the comprehensive performance of the batteries. Researches on separator modification have achieved great effects on Li-S batteries [82–88], while some progress has also been made in Mg-S batteries. Inhibition of polysulfide shuttling by separator modification and design is quite similar between Mg-S and Li-S battery systems, which are mainly obtained through physical barrier, chemical adsorption and electrostatic repulsion of polysulfides by functional materials. However, the difference is that the solubility of Mg-PSs is also considerably lower than lithium polysulfides (Li-PSs) due to the stronger electrostatic interaction of Mg2+ ions with polysulfide ions [28]. Meanwhile, the solid-solid conversion kinetics in Mg-S batteries is worse than that in Li-S batteries, so it is essential to consider the catalytic effect of functional materials on the kinetics of reversible conversion of MgS2 and MgS when performing modification of separators. In addition, utilizing the high electrostatic interactions of Mg2+ ions with surface groups may open new strategies for separator design [50]. In this review, we summarize the research work on the functionalization of separators for Mg-S batteries, and provide an outlook on the development of separators for Mg-S batteries in the context of the numerous studies on separators for Li-S and Mg-S batteries. Furthermore, we presented the application of GPEs coupled with separators in Mg-S batteries, the structure of GPE@separator plays the roles of both ionic conductivity bearer and separator between anode and cathode, and exhibits a promising inhibition of the shuttle effect of Mg-PSs. The results of the research provide a new idea for the design of the separators for Mg-S batteries, and can be regarded as a necessary transition to the all-solid-state Mg-S batteries, which is of extraordinary significance in promoting the development of Mg-S batteries. 2 Working mechanism of Mg-S batteries It is generally believed that the working mechanism of Mg-S batteries is similar to that of Li-S batteries [81,89,90]. During the discharge process of the batteries, metal anode loses electrons and then is oxidized to cations which migrate in the electrolyte to the sulfur cathode through the separator under the concentration difference. The electrons are transferred from the anode to the cathode through the external circuit, and sulfur cathode obtains electrons and is reduced to sulfur anions with different valence states. During this process, the reactions of cations with the reduction products of S8 generate the long-chain S8 2−, which is gradually cleaved to S x 2− (x = 6, 4, 2), and short-chain S2 2− is finally further reduced to sulfide through a solid-state transformation. Subsequently, the charge process proceeds in the opposite direction. In general, four steps can be organized [90]. (1) Step I: S8 + Mg2+ + 2e− → MgS8 (2) Step II: MgS8 + Mg2+ + 2e− → 2MgS4 (3) Step III: MgS4 + Mg2+ + 2e− → 2MgS2 (4) Step Ⅳ: MgS2 + Mg2+ + 2e− → 2MgS It is noteworthy that the specific reaction mechanisms in Mg-S batteries are very complex, and the reaction kinetics and thermodynamics are closely related to the electrolytes and solvents used in the battery system. Bieker et al. [91] and Jalkanen et al. [92] have demonstrated that the redox behaviors of polysulfides in Mg-S and Li-S batteries are strongly cation and solvent dependence. Therefore, there are numerous discrepancies in the literature regarding the actual reaction mechanisms of Mg-S batteries, and there are no clear reaction pathways applicable to any Mg-S battery systems. Zhao-Karger et al. [41] observed two voltage plateaus in exploring the discharge process of Mg-S batteries in Mg(HMDS)2/AlCl3/MgCl2/DG (Mg(HMDS)2 = bis-hexamethyldisilazide magnesium, DG = diglyme) electrolyte and suggested that the reduction process of sulfur cathode in Mg-S batteries can be divided into three stages, i.e., Step I + II, Step III and Step IV (Fig. 2 b). Different from the four stages of the Li-S batteries ((I) S8 → Li2S8, (II) Li2S8 → Li2S4, (III) Li2S4 → Li2S2 + Li2S, (IV) Li2S2 → Li2S) [89,93] (Fig. 2c), in their study, the first stage is the partial reduction of S8 to form long-chain MgS4, which corresponds to the voltage plateau of approximately 1.6 V in the discharge curve. The second stage is the gradual cleavage of long-chain Mg-PSs to short-chain Mg-PSs, which means the continuous reduction of MgS4 to MgS2, corresponding to the sloping voltage in the discharge curve. In the third stage, since S2 2− or S2− is not found in the electrolyte, the process is judged to be a solid-state reaction, meaning that the MgS2 is further reduced to the final product MgS through solid-state conversion. Zhang and co-workers [94] studied the capacity degradation mechanism of Mg-S batteries in 0.5 M [Mg(DG)2][(HMDSAlCl3)]2/DG electrolyte by in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and obtained a similar conclusion to that of Zhao-Karger et al. In addition, Wang et al. [26] studied the thermodynamics and kinetics of sulfur cathode discharge in bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide magnesium/glyme (Mg(TFSI)2/DME), analyzed the forms of polysulfides in the electrolyte during the charge/discharge processes of Mg-S batteries by using the characterization methods such as in-situ Raman spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and provided a mechanism for sulfur transformation: (I) S8 → MgS8, (II) MgS8 → MgS2, and (III) MgS2 → MgS, i.e. corresponding to Step I, Step II + III, Step Ⅳ, as shown in Fig. 2(d). Stage I is similar to the first stage of Li-S batteries, where sulfur is partially reduced to long-chain polysulfides, and the reaction of stage II is accompanied by the shortening of the long-chain polysulfide chain. The sulfur species mainly exists in solid form due to the small solubility of short-chain polysulfides, and the stage III is similar to the fourth stage of the Li-S batteries, with the whole reaction occurring in the solid state. The processes ① and ② represent surface magnesiation and bulk magnesition, respectively. Kinetics of Stages I and II is mixed-controlled, while that of Stage III is diffusion controlled. In addition, only one voltage plateau was observed for the Mg-S battery with tetrakis(hexafluoroisopropyloxy)borate magnesium/gylme (Mg[B(Ohfip)4]2/DME) electrolyte, which is considered as reaction of Steps I–III. Noteworthy, the solid-phase conversion of MgS2 to MgS (Step IV) is believed to be prevalent in all Mg-S battery studies. The reaction of this Step has a high kinetic potential barrier, high polarization, and a large overpotential, so the reaction kinetics is slow, corresponding to a rapid decrease of the discharge potential and an early termination of the discharge [41,93]. In addition to the electrolyte, current density and sulfur loading are also important factors affecting the reaction kinetics of Mg-S batteries. Wang et al further demonstrated that with the gradual increase of sulfur loading and current density, the discharge plateaus of both Step I–III and Step IV become increasingly shorter due to the deterioration of the reaction kinetics, which leads to the early termination of the discharge. How to ensure high sulfur utilization at high sulfur loading and large current densities is also one of the challenges for Mg-S batteries. Introducing materials with catalytic functions into the separators to promote the reversible conversion kinetics of solid-state MgS and improve the sulfur utilization is a feasible strategy, which will be discussed in detail later in the review. 3 Research on Mg-S battery separators The separator is the key components of various liquid electrolyte batteries, which are placed between the cathode and anode to prevent the occurrence of short circuits caused by direct contact of the two electrodes, as well as to ensure the free transport of ions and isolate the flow of electrons [95–98]. The separator affects the specific capacity, power density, and cycle life by directly influencing the interfacial structure and internal resistance of the batteries. Therefore, the research and development of multifunctional separators with excellent performance can greatly improve the comprehensive performance of the batteries, and separator is thus called the “third electrode” of the batteries [99,100]. The separator should have the following basic characteristics in order to ensure proper battery operation: (1) good chemical and electrochemical stability to resist the reaction with the electrolytes and electrode materials, and ensure the complete reactions of active materials; (2) sufficient mechanical strength to withstand the operating tension during battery assembly and operation; (3) uniform thickness to ensure the cycle stability and long cycle life of the batteries; (4) adequate porosity and uniform pore size to absorb the liquid electrolyte and enhance the ionic conductivity [96,101,102]. In addition, the separator with excellent performance should include good wettability and thermal stability, etc. Of course, the price is also one of the factors worth considering. However, the introduction of separator increases the internal resistance, which has a negative impact on the cycle life and rate capability of the batteries. In view of the shuttle effect, the metal-sulfur batteries have higher requirements for the separators, thus the selection of suitable separators and appropriate modification to the separators are of great significance for improving the energy density, cycle stability, and safety performance of the batteries. Commercially available microporous polymer separators and nonwovens are commonly used in most batteries. The separators used in battery systems at operating temperatures close to the environment are usually made of organic materials (such as polymers, cellulose paper, other fabrics, etc.) and inorganic materials (such as asbestos, glass wool, ceramics, SiO2, etc.) [102]. Among them, polyolefin-based separators occupy the majority of the battery separator market, and the metal-sulfur battery systems are no exception. However, with the rapid development of the battery energy market, especially the emergence of new energy vehicles, higher requirements have been put forward for the comprehensive performance of energy storage batteries, including safety performance, energy density, environmental friendliness, etc. It is a feasible strategy to enhance the battery performance via the improvement of separator. There are numerous reports on the design and modification of separators for Li-S batteries, including the modification of conventional separators, the preparation of new composite separators through electrostatic spinning, vacuum filtration and cross-linked polymerization, and the development of composite membrane structures containing gel polymer electrolytes coupled with glass fiber (GF) separators [86]. These strategies have shown effective results in improving the comprehensive performance of Mg-S batteries. Fig. 3 (a) shows the explorations and possible future directions in separators since the report of Mg-S batteries, and Fig. 3(b and c) summarize and compare the different properties of these separators. 3.1 Conventional separator materials The separators of liquid electrolyte battery systems (include rechargeable magnesium batteries (RMBs), sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), LIBs, etc.) are either made of stretched microporous polyolefins or nonwoven fabrics [102]. The most common microporous polyolefin separators on the market are mainly made of polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP), which are usually thin (<30 μm) with good mechanical and insulative properties, excellent chemical and electrochemical stability, as well as low costs [102]. In practical applications, in addition to the two conventional single-layer separators of PE and PP [103], there are also PE/PP double-layer and PP/PE/PP triple-layer composite separators produced by Celgard [102]. The good flexibility of PE material and the oxidation resistance of PP material allow them to be widely used as the separators of power batteries [104]. However, polyolefin microporous membranes are potentially dangerous due to their low thermal stability and heat shrinkage when the temperature is higher than 140 °C. In addition, traditional polyolefin-based separators are non-polar membranes with insufficient porosity (about 40%), resulting in inadequate wetting and absorption of liquid electrolytes, poor affinity with polar liquid electrolytes, which increase the resistance of batteries [105]. In the case of Mg-S battery systems with complex reactions during charge/discharge processes and various types of electrolytes, polyolefin microporous membranes are not well suitable to meet the corresponding needs, especially in inhibiting the diffusion and shuttle effect of the Mg-PSs, which largely deteriorate the cycle performance and lifetime of the batteries [106,107]. Therefore, it is necessary to modify the traditional polyolefin-based separators to meet the functional requirements of Mg-S batteries while maintaining their own advantages, thus suppressing the shuttle effect during the charge/discharge processes and improving the cycling performance of batteries. The raw materials of non-woven membranes include cellulose and its chemically modified derivatives, polyamide (PA), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), polyvinyl chloride (PVC) and polyester, etc., which can be synthesized by physically or chemically combining a large number of fibers [96]. These separators have the advantages of low processing costs, high porosity, and good heat resistance. GF membranes have attracted much attention due to their highly porous structure, excellent electrolyte wetting, and thermal stability, exhibiting high ionic conductivity and rate performance in Li-S batteries [108,109]. However, a majority of non-woven separators cannot play effectively roles for blocking the shuttle of polysulfides due to large pore sizes, and are less commonly used in metal-sulfur battery systems [110,111]. Although conventional microporous polyolefin separators are still dominant in most liquid electrolyte batteries, their deficiencies greatly limit the further development and application of such batteries. Therefore, some explorations have been made on separators in the Mg-S batteries, such as the modification of conventional separators and the design of functional separator through physical or chemical methods, which have played an important role in advancing the development of Mg-S batteries. 3.2 Traditional separators with modification The shuttle effect of Mg-PSs during the cycling of Mg-S batteries is always unavoidable due to the solubility of polysulfides in the electrolytes. The investigations of coating functional materials on top of the traditional separators for the purpose of sulfur fixation have achieved remarkable results in alleviating the diffusion of polysulfides, improving the utilization of active sulfur materials, and enhancing the performance of Mg-S batteries. Physical blocking/adsorption is the most direct strategy to inhibit polysulfide diffusion, and carbon-based materials have been used as separator modification materials due to their adsorption to polysulfides, which has been extensively reported in Li-S batteries [85–87,112]. Furthermore, carbon materials have the advantages of adjustable pore structures, large specific surface areas, and excellent electrical conductivities. Therefore, coating porous carbon materials such as conductive carbon black (Super P), micro/mesoporous carbons, and carbon nanotubes on the cathode side of the separators as a functionalized intercalation layer can not only effectively limit the shuttling of polysulfides and regulate the distribution of active substances, but also help to further reduce the cathode interfacial impedance and promote the electron conduction, thus improving the electrochemical performance of the Mg-S batteries. Manthiram et al. [58] prepared a coated separator (CNF-GF) by depositing a layer of thin activated carbon nanofiber powder (CNF) on a GF separator via the vacuum filtration method, and the areal mass of CNF coating is about 0.2 mg cm−2, as shown in Fig. 4 (a–c). In comparison with that using conventional GF separator, the cell with CNF-coated separator shows more stable, higher discharge capacity and higher Coulombic efficiency (Fig. 4d and e). The battery with CNF-GF separator and Mg(HMDS)2-AlCl3-MgCl2/TEGDME (TEGDME = tetraglyme) electrolyte delivers a considerable discharge capacity of approximately 1200 mA h g−1 at a rate of C/50, and there is no rapid capacity decrease at C/20 and C/10 (Fig. 4f). The elemental sulfur found in the CNF coating indicates that the dissolved intermediate products Mg-PSs diffuse into the CNF during the cycling process. The unique porous structure of the CNF can absorb these diffusing active components and inhibit their further diffusion to the Mg anode through the separator, which would lead to side reactions and metal Mg passivation. Meanwhile, the electronical conductivity of the CNF enables it to act as a secondary collector, which can electrochemically deposit sulfur materials and promote the polysulfides to be discharged and charged back to the CNF matrix, thus ensuring that Mg-PSs are re-involved in the electrochemical reaction, improving the utilization of the active sulfur materials, and increasing the cycling capacity of the Mg-S batteries. In addition, the good porosity of CNF coating can alleviate the volume effect of sulfur cathode during battery operation, further enhancing the cycle stability and life of the batteries [113]. Monotonous physical adsorption has a limited inhibitory effect on the Mg-S shuttle effect and cannot play a favorable role in promoting the conversion kinetics of solid MgS2 and MgS. Therefore, it is necessary to introduce modified materials that have stronger chemical affinity with polar polysulfides. For example, metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal nitrides, metal phosphides, and other inorganic materials with polar sites have excellent chemisorption and physisorption effects on polysulfides, as well as superior catalytic effect on the kinetics of the reversible conversion of MgS2/MgS due to the special electronic structures and chemical properties of these materials. Tang et al. [114] prepared a MoS2 coated separator for Li-S batteries, which effectively inhibited the migration of lithium polysulfides and the growth of lithium dendrites, facilitated the deposition and conversion of lithium polysulfides, and achieved high-level cycling performance of Li-S batteries. Similarly, Zhao-Karger et al. [115] uniformly casted a Chevrel phase (CP) Mo6S8 slurry on one side of the conventional Celgard separator (CG) to form a functional coated separator (CG@CP) with an average thickness of 20 μm. Fig. 5 (a–c) show that compared with the original CG and carbon coated separator (CG@C), the battery with CG@CP has a significant effect on achieving stable cycles with higher Coulombic efficiency (96%) and better rate performance in 0.3 M Mg[B(Ohfip)4]2/DME electrolyte, which is mainly attributed to the high affinity of Mo6S8 for polysulfides (Fig. 5e–h), facilitating the capture of polysulfides and thus minimizing the shuttle effect. In addition, density function theory (DFT) calculation supports that Chevrel phase Mo6S8 may also promote the conversion reaction of polysulfides and improve the redox reversibility of the active sulfur species, which contributes to the kinetic reaction of the Mg-S batteries. However, despite the high discharge capacity of 942.9 mA h g−1 exhibited in the first cycle, the charge/discharge curves of the first three cycles demonstrate that the CG@CP-based battery still suffers from a rapid capacity decay (Fig. 5d), which is also the major challenge for Mg-S batteries and needs to be further addressed. Furthermore, Mo6S8, a common cathode for RMBs, is an electrochemically active component based on the redox reaction of Mo6S8 ↔ Mg x Mo6S8, which is used as a functional coating for Mg-S battery separator in this report, and whether the effect on battery capacity is negligible should be illustrated by further investigation [17,116,117]. In addition to molybdenum sulfides, other metal sulfides such as WS2 [118], Co9S8 [119], Sb2S3 [120], ReS2 [121], and VS4 [122] can be used as separator modification materials for Mg-S batteries in an attempted manner. Metal phosphides, especially transition metal phosphides, are particularly suitable as separator modification materials for metal-sulfur batteries due to their high electrical conductivities, good thermal stability, excellent electrocatalytic properties, and tunable porous structures [123,124]. For instance, Zhao et al. [124] reported that cobalt phosphide/carbon (CoP/C) nanocubic conductive layer in Li-S batteries not only anchors polysulfides by physical and chemical methods, but also improves the electrochemical activity and reaction kinetics of Li-S batteries. Recently, NuLi et al. [125] utilized a copper phosphide (Cu3P) modified separator to achieve the adsorption of Mg-PSs and catalyze the reversible reaction of S and Mg2+ ions toward the stable cycling of Mg-S cells, thus overcoming the problems of fast capacity decay and short cycle life of the batteries. Micro-octahedral Cu3P was confined in carbon nano-matrix to form a Cu3P@C composite, which was constructed on the commercial PP separator via slurry coating with the assistance of polyvinylidene fluoride/N-Methylpyrrolidone (PVDF/NMP) to form a PP-Cu3P@C dual-functional porous membrane with high electrolyte wettability and good thermal stability (Fig. 6 a–c). The functional coating layer with thickness of ∼7 μm, as a conductive barrier layer, can improve the utilization of sulfur by reducing the internal resistance of the cells. Moreover, the excellent wettability of Cu3P@C facilitates the absorption of electrolyte and enhances ion transport efficiency. Despite the surface becomes blurred due to the effect of the polymer binder, the Cu3P@C particles on the separator can keep the initial profile (Fig. 6d), which means the structure stability of the functional layer during cycles. DFT calculations and polysulfide permeability tests indicate that the Cu3P catalytic layer can effectively adsorb polysulfides via surface interactions and promote their rapid conversion, thus greatly reducing the dissolution and diffusion of polysulfides and promoting the electrochemical reversibility of the Mg-S cells (Fig. 6e–g). In Mg[B(Ohfip)4]2/DME electrolyte, compared with that using conventional PP separator alone, the Mg-S cell based on PP-Cu3P@C separator achieved higher cycle specific capacities (449 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C and 249 mA h g−1 at 1.0 C), faster rates, better cycling stability, and longer cycle life (stable for more than 500 cycles and maintained a high specific capacity of 152 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles with only 0.097% capacity decay per cycle), as shown in Fig. 6(h and i). Interesting, the Mg-S cells based on the dual-functional separator showed excellent electrochemical performance even at high temperatures, which could also be attributed to the adsorptive and catalytic Cu3P@C layer that minimizes the shuttle effect of polysulfides and promotes the electrochemical conversion of Mg-PSs, while the high thermal stability provided an advantage for Mg-S cells operating at high temperatures. Metal oxides can anchor polysulfides by physical and chemical methods like metal sulfides and phosphides, and attractively, metal oxides contain abundant active sites that contribute to the redox kinetics of polysulfides, thus possessing a unique advantage as separator modification materials [126–133]. However, there is still a gap of reports on metal oxides as separator modification materials in Mg-S batteries, which may be limited by the electron-insulating nature of metal oxides. As a substitute, metal nitrides can also be considered as separator modification materials for Mg-S batteries due to their favorable electrical conductivity and strong chemical interactions with polysulfides [134–139]. Moreover, considering that some transition and precious metals have excellent electrocatalytic effect on polysulfide conversion, which contributes to accelerate the reaction kinetics in the solid-state conversion stage of Mg-S batteries and promote the reversible conversion of short-chained Mg-PSs, it would be interesting to design a catalytic separator with transition metals as the conductive centers in order to achieve a high-level electrochemical performance of Mg-S batteries, and the feasibility of such an idea has already been verified in Li-S batteries [140–142]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are also coated on the surface of conventional separators to form functional separators and used in Mg-S batteries to ameliorate the shuttle effect of polysulfides due to the interaction between POMs with sulfur species. The POMs are a group of polyanionic metal oxides composed of metal ions and oxo ligands of tungsten (W), vanadium (V), molybdenum (Mo), tantalum (Ta), etc., which offer good electrochemical redox properties and diverse electronic structures, as well as advantages in multi-molecular integration, thus are widely used in the preparation, catalysis and energy storage of functional materials [143–147]. Zhou et al. [148] obtained a so-called “polysulfide-phobic” separator by coating two-dimensional (2D) VOPO4 sheets onto the PP microporous membrane and applied it in Li-S batteries, which can effectively prevent the diffusion of polysulfides due to the intramolecular interaction between vanadium and active sulfur species, thus high reversible capacity of Li-S batteries was achieved. Su et al. [144] prepared a dual-functional composite coated separator by coating a layer of Keggin-type polyoxometalate [PW12O40]3−/Super P composite on the conventional PP separator, which effectively blocks the shuttle of polysulfides in Li-S batteries due to the coulombic repulsion between POMs and polysulfide anions. While the POMs composite separator can maintain structural integrity during the charge/discharge processes, reducing the capacity decay and enhancing the cycling stability of the batteries. In a similar manner, Zhao-Karger et al. [149] obtained a POM/C GF separator (denoted as es.-POM/C), which contains a [TBA3V10]-based homogeneous coating, by loading a mixed slurry of tetrabutylammonium decavanadate (TBA3[H3V10O28]) clusters (abbreviated as TBA3V10) with Super P and PVDF onto one side of the Whatman GF separator via an electrostatic spinning technique (Fig. 7 a), and the mass loading was calculated as 0.5 mg cm−2. Compared to vacuum deposition and scraper coating with a squeegee, the electrostatic spinning technique has the advantages of functional versatility, size controllability, and mass production, thus facilitating the formation of more uniform coatings and the loading of much easier control [150–152]. The es.-POM/C separator has significant ability to inhibit polysulfide diffusion compared to the conventional GF separator, as shown in Fig. 7(b). Correspondingly, the Mg-S cells containing the modified separator show significantly enhanced cycling capacity and stability, providing a high specific capacity of about 320 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles in Mg[B(Ohfip)4]2/DME electrolyte (Fig. 7c and d), which is mainly attributed to the adsorption of polysulfides by the carbon materials on the separator to avoid the passivation of the metal Mg anode. Furthermore, notably narrow redox CV signals of es.-POM/C cells indicate a possible chemical interaction between POMs and sulfur species (Fig. 7e and f), which allows the polysulfides to be reactivated and involved in the cell reactions again, thus improving the utilization of the active material sulfur, and promoting the reversibility of redox chemistry. The method of inhibiting polysulfide shuttling by coating functional materials on the surface of polyolefin-based separators or GF membranes is not only effective but also feasible and simple to implement, and can be synergistically applied in the development of electrolytes for Mg-S batteries or in the study of cathode materials. For example, Li et al. [49] also used reduced graphene (RGO) to modify the GF membrane in the process of exploring metal organic frameworks (MOFs) derived carbon as S carriers to trap soluble polysulfides, thus inhibiting the diffusion of polysulfides and further improving the cycling performance of Mg-S batteries. When modification is performed on the separators by inorganic compound material coating, the thickness or mass loading, the wettability of the electrolytes, and the ionic conductivities of the coating materials themself should be conscientiously designed in addition to the consideration of their adsorption and catalytic conversion to polysulfides. For example, a thin coating layer will decrease the limitation to polysulfide migration, while an increase in the coating thickness will reduce the porosity and impact the rate performance and energy density of the batteries. Therefore, the loading of the functional coating on the separator needs to be strictly controlled. In principle, it is a major challenge in the design of coated modified separators to effectively achieve uniform dispersion and reasonable distribution of functional materials. In addition, DFT allows the calculation of interaction energies (such as binding energies) between modified materials and polysulfides, and also analyzes the energy band structures of the modified materials, the charge distribution of polysulfides on the coatings, the bond-breaking energy barriers, and the conversion energy barriers, etc. [153], which could lead to a deeper comprehension on the contribution of the coated materials to the enhancement of the battery performance. For instance, DFT calculations have shown that there are strong binding energies between inorganic materials such as metal sulfides or phosphides and polysulfides, which are favorable for the adsorption of polysulfides. In addition, the presence of catalytic modified materials reduces the energy required to break the S–S bond and the potential barrier for MgSx conversion, which facilitates the polysulfide conversion and promotes the reaction kinetics of the batteries. On the basis of in-depth theoretical understanding of the interaction between the modified materials and polysulfides, the selection of coating materials can be further optimized or novel materials more suitable for the separator modification of Mg-S batteries can be developed with the help of DFT calculations, thus promoting the development of Mg-S batteries. 3.3 Non-polyolefin/GF-based separators Functionalized polyolefin-based separators can certainly play a good role in suppressing the shuttle effect of polysulfides during the operation of Mg-S batteries, and also improve the utilization of active material sulfur. However, the impact of the inherent internal resistance of conventional separators on the cycling performance of batteries still cannot be ignored, and the shrinkage problem of polyolefin-based separators under high temperature conditions can also cause significant safety hazards [154]. Therefore, it is of great research significance to develop and design new functional separators without polyolefin-based membranes as the substrates, in order to further improve the performance of Mg-S batteries and promote their development. Re-designing functionalized separators from a fundamental polymer perspective is also an essential strategy to achieve the development of Mg-S batteries. In Li-S batteries, polyethylene glycol (PEG) [155], polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) [156], ammonium alcohol polyvinyl phosphate (AAPP) [157], polypyrrole (PPy) [158], polystyrene (PS) [159] and other functionalized polymer separator materials have been well considered. In addition, polyimide (PI) nonwovens have been used as the separators of high temperature lithium-ion batteries due to their high dimensional stability, good electrolyte wettability, and excellent heat tolerance [160–164]. On this basis, Zhao and co-workers [165] used electrospun PI nonwovens as the main body to design a novel multifunctional separator based on the non-polyolefin membrane. PI was coated with copper nanowire-graphene nanosheet (CuNWs-GN) film on one side and a rigid lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide polyethylene oxide (LLZO-PEO) film on the other side, forming an interlayer separator (CuNWs-GN/PI/LLZO) with a sandwich structure, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). The thickness of the CuNWs-GN/PI/LLZO membrane is about 26 µm, in which the CuNWs-GN film is only around 2 µm. The functionalized separator retained the advantages of PI, while the coatings on both sides compensated for the inability of PI separators to inhibit Li dendrite growth and effectively block polysulfide shuttle. In addition, besides its strong polysulfide barrier capability through physical adsorption and chemical anchoring, the CuNWs-GN coating also acted as an electrochemical catalyst during the polysulfide conversion process, which further contributed to the cycling performance (Fig. 8b). The Li-S cells with the CuNWs-GN/PI/LLZO separator exhibited excellent cycling performance at 80 °C, with an average capacity loss of only 0.24% per cycle over 300 cycles at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 (Fig. 8c). The Mg-S cells based on the CuNWs-GN/PI/LLZO separator also showed an impressive cycling performance at 50 °C, maintaining a high capacity of 915.3 mA h g−1 after 25 cycles (Fig. 8d). It is worth noting that CuNWs did not increase the internal resistance of the cells. On the contrary, the cells with the CuNWs-GN/PI/LLZO separator showed significantly reduced internal resistance and high cycle reversibility compared with the two CuNWs-free composite separators, GN/PI/LLZO and C/PI/LLZO (Fig. 8e and f). In addition to physical and chemical adsorption, electrostatic repulsion is also an effective method to limit the migration of polysulfides. The cross-linked polymer separators containing abundant charged functional groups are formed by selecting reasonable monomers, which not only improve the interfacial conductivity and mechanical properties, but also inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfides via the synergistic effects of physical barrier, chemical adsorption, and electrostatic repulsion, and thus improving the cycling stability. A cross-linked ionomer gel separator for the inhibition of polysulfide shuttle in Mg-S cells was reported by Schaefer et al. [166] A cross-linked network of tethered anionic groups bridged by PEG linkers was formed by copolymerizing poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate or dimethacrylate (PEGDA/PEGDMA) with ionic monomers (Fig. 9 a). This structure mitigated the shuttling of Mg-PSs by physical adsorption/barrier and electrostatic repulsion, i.e., the cross-linked networks bridged by PEG linkers of different chain lengths exhibited different effective pore sizes, thus physically absorbing/restricting the shuttling of polysulfides (Fig. 9e). Moreover, when the separator swelled in the electrolyte, a certain degree of tethered anions would dissociate and electrostatically repel the negatively charged polysulfide anions dissolved in the electrolyte, thus reducing the diffusion of Mg-PSs (Fig. 9b–d). Therefore, a better polysulfide barrier can be achieved by adjusting the lengths of the PEG linkers, tethered anions chemistry, and the ratios of charge to ether oxygen (Ch:EO). Unfortunately, the capacity degradation of the Mg-S batteries with this cross-linked ionomer gel separator was not well alleviated, mainly because the cross-linked network structure absorbed the active polysulfides, and they could not be completely reversibly released back to the cathode to continue to participate in the electrochemical reaction. As a result, only some of the active materials were reused, which means that the utilization of the sulfur is not well improved. Furthermore, the compromised transport of cations in the system and the poor kinetics between higher-order polysulfides and MgS2/MgS in Mg-S batteries are also essential factors for the capacity decay [167]. In addition, functionalized cross-linked polymer separators inevitably cause additional cation diffusion resistance while achieving selective ion transport and improving the uniformity of ion distribution, which has an impact on the rate performance and polarization characteristics of the batteries. Nevertheless, this work provides an interesting idea of designing multifunctional separators with electrostatic repulsion and non-separator substrate to suppress the shuttle effect of polysulfides in Mg-S batteries, which is a good inspiration for the research in this field. In addition, when cross-linked polymer separators are designed, inorganic materials such as transition metal oxides, sulfides, or phosphides that can catalyze the redox kinetics of polysulfides can be introduced to reduce the accumulation of “dead sulfur”, improve the utilization of active sulfur, and enhance the electrochemical performance of the batteries. 3.4 Gel polymer electrolytes coupled separators The development of Mg-S batteries has long been severely limited by the electrolytes. The electrophilic sulfur cathode limits the application of nucleophilic electrolytes in Mg-S batteries, so researchers have been active in exploring non-nucleophilic electrolytes for Mg-S batteries [81]. The current non-nucleophilic electrolytes for Mg-S battery systems mainly include a series of electrolytes based on Mg(HMDS)2 [27,41,168–170], boron-based weakly coordinated anionic electrolytes with boron atoms as the center [44,171–174], in which Mg[B(Ohfip)4]2 reported by Zhao-Karger et al. [173] showed excellent electrochemical properties and has been widely used. In addition, Mg(TFSI)2 electrolyte has also been explored in Mg-S batteries [26,75,175,176], but the TFSI− anion induced passivation of the Mg anode needs to be taken into account. Cui et al. [43] provided a summary of electrolytes for RMBs that have been explored so far, as shown in Fig. 10 , and the electrolytes of the Mg-S batteries are also included in the figure. The design of non-nucleophilic Mg2+ electrolytes has facilitated the development of Mg-S batteries. However, most of these electrolytes used in current research on separator modification are liquid, which are associated with safety issues such as leakage, and are one of the main culprits for the dissolution and shuttling of polysulfides in metal-sulfur battery systems. It has been revealed that due to the shuttle effect, Mg-S batteries show a high tendency of rapid self-discharge in traditional liquid electrolytes, leading to severe capacity loss in the initial cycle [177–179]. Therefore, suppressing the shuttle effect by reducing the dissolution and diffusion of polysulfides in the electrolytes is an implementable solution, and the application schemes of quasi-solid electrolytes in Mg-S batteries are proposed. Combining electrolyte design and separator modification, a gel electrolyte coupled with separator structure has been proposed to improve the electrochemical performance of Mg-S batteries. It worth nothing that there are overlaps between the research on separator modification and the development of a wide range of GPEs, where polymers have highly adjustable and scalable capabilities and show great potential for applications in ion transport and regulation [180]. In the research proposals of gel polymer electrolytes, polymers can not only be served as carriers for ion conduction, but some self-supporting GPEs can also be used as separators. In the field of metal-sulfur batteries, suitable polymer electrolyte materials conduct the active cations and selectively block or repel active polysulfides through the cross-linked network structures or electrostatic interaction, thereby inhibiting the shuttle effect. Schaefer et al. [180] has investigated the effects of the network cation solvation capacity of GPEs on the interactions of polysulfides and polymers, and demonstrated that GPE membranes contribute to the cycling stability and lifetime of Mg-S batteries via suppression of shullte effect. However, mechanical strength of the GPE film is insufficient, and the utilization of the active material sulfur is low. By coupling the gel polymer electrolyte with the GF separator, a dual-functional structure combining the conduction of ions and the inhibition of polysulfide diffusion was formed, which significantly improved the performance of Mg-S batteries. In comparison to liquid electrolytes, GPEs would offer tremendous advantages for RMBs, such as higher safety, no internal short circuits and electrolyte leakage, natural advantage of high temperature resistance, and ease of fabrication and structural flexibility, etc. [181–183]. Cui et al. [184] synthesized a novel polytetrahydrofuran (PTHF)-borate-based gel polymer electrolyte coupled with a GF membrane (PTB@GF-GPE) with the thickness of 50 μm by in-situ cross-linking reaction of magnesium borohydride [Mg(BH4)2] and hydroxyl terminated PTHF with a certain percentage of MgCl2 and using the porous GF membrane as the supporting substrate, as shown in Fig. 11 (a and b). The interpenetration of PTB-GPE and GF membrane improved the mechanical properties and flexibility of the PTB@GF-GPE. However, the use of MgCl2 reduces the anodic stability of the electrolyte on stainless steel (SS) due to the electrochemical corrosion of chlorine-containing components to non-precious metals, thus limiting its practical application [44]. Based on the idea, Zhao-Karger et al. [185] similarly synthesized a GPE@GF by in-situ polymerization of Mg(BH4)2 and PTHF with a GF membrane as a mechanical support, and the thickness of the GPE@GF was measured as 52 μm. In contrast to the work of Cui et al., they chose chlorine-free Mg[B(Ohfip)4]2 (MgBOR) instead of MgCl2 to form MgBOR-PTHF-GPE@GF composite structure with both ionic conductivity and polysulfide barrier function (Fig. 12 a). The study results in Mg-S batteries with the activated carbon cloth-based sulfur (ACC/S) cathode reveal that the MgBOR-PTHF-GPE@GF structure showed good compatibility with both Mg anode and sulfur cathode, as well as high ionic conductivity and the ability to mitigate the self-discharge behavior of Mg-S batteries. Compared with the liquid electrolyte, the MgBOR-PTHF-GPE system exhibits higher cycling capacity and stability as well as a slower capacity decay trend (Fig. 12b–d), which can be attributed to the polymeric gel network structure of the GPE that can trap solvent molecules and thus retain sufficient Mg2+ ions conductivity, while limiting the dissolution and shuttle of polysulfides. Furthermore, the Mg[B(Ohfip)4]2-based GPE can be extended to different polymer backbones. The polymerization of pentaerythritol tetraacrylate (PETEA) as a monomer, for example, has been reported in metal-sulfur batteries [186,187]. Zhao-Karger et al. further used azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) to initiate the polymerization of PETEA in MgBOR liquid electrolyte to obtain MOBR-PETEA-GPE@GF (Fig. 12e). The ACC/S cell based on this GPE had only a small capacity degradation in the first three cycles (Fig. 12f). However, although both of PTHF-GPE and PETEA-GPE exhibited higher Coulombic efficiency compared to the liquid electrolyte, both had low capacity retention in terms of long-term cycling (Fig. 12g and h), which may be related to irreversible blockage of polysulfides in the GPE. Zhang et al. [188] reported a non-nucleophilic gel polymer electrolyte coupled with a GF separator (MgCl-FTGB@GF) based on MgCl2-Mg(BH4)2-fluorinated tetraethylene glycol (MgCl-FTGB) (Fig. 13 a–c), the thickness of MgCl-FTGB@GF was measured as 50 μm. The GPE showed high Mg2+ ions transfer number and oxidative stability (4.8 V vs. Mg/Mg2+), and good compatibility with Mg anode for reversible Mg deposition/dissolution with low polarization and high Coulombic efficiency (about 100%). The Mg-S battery assembled with the MgCl-FTGB@GF electrolyte maintained a high specific discharge capacity of over 1100 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles (Fig. 13d), indicative of the significant enhancement of Mg-S battery performance via this GPE@GF. The cutting and folding experiments further demonstrated the good safety and flexibility of Mg-S pouch batteries based on the MgCl-FTGB@GF electrolyte. These studies provide a possible research strategy for future Mg-S batteries with safety, flexibility, and high specific capacity. Wang et al. [189] prepared a novel halogen-free Mg2+/Li+ double salt-based GPE (referred to MLT-GPE) by in-situ cross-linking polymerization of Mg/Li borohydrides [Mg(BH4)2, Li(BH4)] and PTHF with GF as mechanical carrier and reaction site as well as TiO2 nanoparticles as an additive (Fig. 14 a and b), which was compatible with a wide range of sulfur-based and intercalated cathodes. The TiO2 nanoparticle additive functioned by improving the conductivity and mechanical properties of the electrolyte, and trapping polysulfides to a certain extent [190]. Fig. 14(c) illustrates that the Mg||MLT-GPE||SPAN cell with sulfur@poly(acrylonitrile) (SPAN) as the cathode provides an initial discharge capacity of 908 mA h g−1 and a stable cycling capacity of 580 mA h g−1. In contrast, the Mg-SPAN cell using the same Mg2+/Li+ salt liquid electrolyte (also with TiO2 added) showed severe capacity decay after the third cycle (Fig. 14d). In addition, the Mg||MLT-GPE||ACC/S cell with ACC/S as the cathode delivered similar results, demonstrating the effective suppression of the polysulfide shuttling by the MLT-GPE, while providing a good contribution to the discharge capacity, cycle reversibility, and rate performance of the Mg-S batteries (Fig. 14e and f). Notably, no MgS was found on the Mg anode after cycling the MLT-GPE-based battery (Fig. 14g and h), which further indicated that the passivation reaction of polysulfides with Mg metal was blocked. Furthermore, this MLT-GPE also exhibited good cycling stability, high Coulombic efficiency and excellent rate performance for intercalated cathode materials such as Chevrel phase Mo6S8, TiS2, and spinel Li4Ti5O12 (LTO). Furthermore, GF will be unnecessary when the mechanical strength of the GPE is great enough to completely prevent contact between anode and cathode, which reduces the internal resistance of the batteries and further improves cycling performance. Cui et al. [191] developed a self-supporting single-ion polymer electrolyte (PECH-OMgCl@G3, SSPE) based on polyepichlorohydrin (PECH) plasticized by triglyme (G3), as shown in Fig. 15 (a). This SSPE had a wide electrochemical stability window (4.8 V vs. Mg2+/Mg), a remarkable Mg2+ ion transference number (0.79) and a highly reversible Mg deposition/dissolution performance. In addition, PECH-OMgCl@G3 exhibited a robust self-supporting structure that acted as both an electrolyte and a separator, thus eliminating the need for conventional polyolefin separators or GF and reducing the impedance caused by the separators. Furthermore, the extremely strong adhesion between the SSPE and Mg metal can further reduce the interfacial impedance, thus improving the electrochemical performance of the batteries [192]. Fig. 15(b) compares the dimensional stability of PECH-OMgCl@G3 membrane and various separators commonly used in Mg-S batteries at elevated temperatures, which reveals the high temperature stability of both the SSPE and GF membranes, while the polyolefin-based separators PP and PE already show inherent large shrinkage at 120 °C. Therefore, this design concept of the robust SSPE provides a promising method for safe operation of RMBs at high temperatures, expanding the possible application scenarios of RMBs. This also provides new ways for the development of functionalized electrolytes and proposes new ideas for the separator modification in Mg-S batteries. The structure design of the gel polymer electrolytes coupled with separators not only improves the safety of the batteries, but also effectively limits the shuttle effect of Mg-PSs, realizing the high-level cycling performance and long cycle life of Mg-S batteries. However, GPE@GF lacks the catalytic effect on the redox kinetics of polysulfides compared with the coated modified separators. The next step can be considered to introduce inorganic compound materials with catalytic conversion effect on polysulfides (referring to coating-modified materials) in the GPE@GF structures at the same time, as a way to promote the reversible conversion kinetics of MgS2/MgS, which can further improve the electrochemical performance of Mg-S batteries and promote their development. 4 Conclusions and outlook It is practical and feasible to enhance the cycle performance of Mg-S batteries by designing or modifying traditional separators. The modified separators and the novel composite separators have been proven to effectively suppress the shuttle effect of polysulfide species in Mg-S batteries through physical adsorption, chemical interaction, and electrostatic repulsion, thereby increasing the utilization of active sulfur and the cycle performance, and extending the cycle life of the batteries. In contrast to the extensive research on Li-S batteries, the investigation of Mg-S batteries is still in the proof-of-concept stage, and the studies on Mg-S battery separators are even less. We present a brief overview of the commonly used separators for Mg-S batteries and highlight the efforts made by researchers in designing and modifying separators to address the shuttle effect of polysulfides. Separator modification is usually achieved by coating functional materials on the surface of polyolefin or GF separators to inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides. Due to the multifunctionality of the coating materials, coated separators can not only adsorb polysulfides, but also catalyze the reversible conversion of polysulfides, thus improving the slow kinetic performance of Mg-S batteries. However, the presence of coating films can also cause undesirable negative effects, such as hindering the transport efficiency of Mg2+ ions and increasing additional interfacial impedance. In addition, unstable coating components may deteriorate the batteries instead. Therefore, the adhesion of functional materials on the separators and the interface electrochemistry should be taken into account when coating modification of polyolefin-based separators is carried out, in order to obtain high-performance composite separators with good stability and low interface impedance. Meanwhile, the ideal separator coating should also have enhanced thermal stability, high electrolyte wettability, simple preparation process and low material costs to achieve satisfactory battery performance and drive Mg-S batteries to the market. The novel gel polymer separators formed by cross-linking polymerization can efficiently inhibit the shuttle phenomenon of polysulfide through physical adsorption and electrostatic repulsion, and the development of cross-linked polymer separators provides a possible solution for the separator modification of Mg-S batteries. Unfortunately, gel polymer separators show insufficient performance in alleviating the capacity degradation of Mg-S batteries, which is mainly attributed to the low utilization of sulfur materials. The adsorption of polysulfides reduces the passivation reaction on the metal anode, but the rapid conversion of polysulfides is also an essential factor to be considered for the functionalized separators. A reasonable design of the charge ratio of the cross-linked structures helps to accelerate the ion transport efficiency and improve the utilization of the active material sulfur. In addition, adding appropriate electrocatalysts to the polymers could facilitate the rapid conversion of polysulfides, thus increasing the cycling capacity and reducing the capacity degradation of the batteries [193–196]. The application of the gel polymer electrolytes and the formation of structures coupled with glass fibers are also effective in suppressing the shuttle effect of Mg-S batteries, which is mainly attributed to the inhibition of polysulfide diffusion by the cross-linked network structures of GPEs. In addition, the use of GPEs can improve the safety of the batteries and further enhance the cycling performance of Mg-S batteries. More interestingly, the development of self-supporting polymer electrolytes can even eliminate the use of conventional separators, thus effectively reducing the internal resistance of the batteries, which is of beneficial significance for the development of electrolytes and the modification of separators in Mg-S batteries. All in all, the performance of the separators for Mg-S batteries can be improved from the coating modification of conventional separators, the structure design of cross-linked polymerization, and the development of GPEs, etc. In addition, some materials with special structures have also been used for separator modification, such as metal-organic framework (MOF) and covalent organic framework (COF) materials with periodic porous networks. They have high functionality, high porosities, adjustable pore sizes, and good thermal stability, and have been reported for the separator modification of Li-S batteries [197–201]. There are also some inspirations for the research in Mg-S batteries. However, it is difficult to completely solve the shuttle problem in Mg-S batteries solely through the modification of the separators. In order to further promote Mg-S batteries to the market, the interaction between separators, electrolytes and electrode materials should be considered comprehensively. In addition, the development of all-solid-state electrolytes (ASSEs) can be expanded from separator modification, since ASSEs act as both separators and ionic conductors. Currently, there are a few studies on ASSEs for RMBs, which mainly include polymer solid-state electrolytes, inorganic solid-state electrolytes and MOF-based solid-state electrolytes [16]. However, these ASSEs generally suffer from low ionic conductivity, poor electrode/electrolyte compatibility, and high interfacial impedance, and it has been a challenge to improve the room-temperature conductivity of the ASSEs and to realize the rapid movement of Mg2+ ions in the solid materials. In this regard, inspiration may be gained from the experience and lessons of the sophisticated Li+ solid state electrolytes [202]. Several ideas have been proposed to address the issues of solid-state electrolytes, such as (1) facilitating the transfer of Mg2+ ions by optimizing the material structures, (2) introducing materials with high electrical conductivity such as carbon nanotubes to improve the conductivity, and (3) with in-depth understanding of the fundamental theories, developing more advanced solid-state materials through an interdisciplinary approach to optimize the material structures and compositions more rationally, such as by utilizing AI calculations. The investigations of ASSEs in Mg-S battery systems are still in a gap state, which may be inextricably linked to the reduction mechanism of polysulfides. In solid-state electrolytes, polysulfides exist in solid state, perhaps leading to slower reaction kinetics, while the migration rate of Mg2+ ions is also slow. Consequentially, the malignant combination of the above two may prevent the full cells from functioning properly. Therefore, there is still a long way to go for the application of ASSEs in Mg-S batteries, and some ideas can perhaps be considered. (1) Starting from the improvement and design of GPEs and slowly transitioning to the development and application of ASSEs, (2) modification and design of reported solid-state electrolytes for RMBs, such as the introduction of electrocatalysts to promote the redox kinetics of polysulfides, (3) exploitation and design of novel polymeric or inorganic conductive materials that can realize high Mg2+ ions conductivity and catalytic effect on the transformation of polysulfides. In summary, the development of ASSEs with high ionic conductivity will be a milestone for the development of Mg-S batteries and even in the field of the whole metal-sulfur batteries. The replacement of organic liquid electrolytes with ASSEs can greatly inhibit the diffusion of polysulfides, effectively solving the shuttle effect problem of Mg-S batteries, while eliminating the use of separators and reducing the internal impedance caused by separators. Furthermore, the development of ASSEs can greatly solve the safety issues of Mg-S batteries, which is conducive to the practical large-scale application, and ideally suited to the high requirements for energy storage devices in the future. Shaopeng Chen is currently pursuing his Master’s Degree under the supervision of Prof. Yanna NuLi at School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University and received his Bachelor’s Degree at Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 2021. His research interests are in gel polymer electrolyte applications in the rechargeable magnesium batteries. Yanna NuLi received her Ph.D. degree from Fudan University in 2001. After completing her postdoctoral research at Fudan, she joined Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 2003. Her main research interests focus on rechargeable magnesium batteries with high energy densities, including Mg-S, Mg-air, aqueous Mg-ion batteries, and Mg2+-Li+ hybrid batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Magnesium-sulfur (Mg-S) batteries have attracted wide research attention in recent years, and are considered as one of the major candidates to replace lithium-ion batteries due to the high theoretical energy density, low costs of active materials, and high safety. However, there are still significant challenges that need to be overcome before they can reach the large-scale practical applications. The key issue is the dissolution and shuttle effect of magnesium polysulfides (Mg-PSs), which leads to severe capacity degradation and shortens cycling life, greatly limiting the development of Mg-S batteries. In order to overcome these challenges, great efforts have been made in cathode materials, electrolytes, and separators. Herein, we review the investigations on suppressing the shuttle effect of Mg-PSs via the modification of separators, including schemes such as coating the functional materials that can hold Mg-PSs on the surface of polyolefin-based or glass fiber (GF) separators, forming gel polymer separators via cross-linking polymerization reactions, and developing gel polymer electrolytes coupled with GF separators. Furthermore, an outlook is proposed for the future design on separator exploitation to accelerate the development of Mg-S battery technology.
